Award.AbstractNarration:
SES-1528703
Matthew Mahutga
University of California-Riverside

The causes of rising income inequality in advanced capitalist countries are not well understood by social scientists despite more than two decades of dedicated research. This project synthesizes literatures on the two most common researched causes of the increase in inequality: globalization and institutions. It advances both of these literatures by providing an explanation for the paradoxical findings on the distributional effects of economic globalization. This explanation identifies specific mechanisms by which globalization and national institutions interact to produce distinct distributional outcomes across time and space.

This study subjects the arguments to empirical scrutiny, a multilevel analysis of the Luxembourg Income Study's (LIS) individual wage data will be conducted. The bulk of NSF funds will support the harmonization of country-specific occupational categories in order to measure skill and work-place authority more directly than is currently possible, because both of these factors are the key mechanisms by which production globalization should affect inequality. In addition to advancing basic research on the causes of rising income inequality among advanced industrial democracies, this project will provide evidence-based assessments of the future implications of production globalization for income inequality, and of policy options at both the macro and micro levels. In tandem, these can help to ameliorate the impact of production globalization on income inequality, low-skill labor, and labor more generally, in the coming decades.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project has two primary goals. The first is to build a dataset of four individual level covariates capturing the “skill,” (occa1 and occb1) “routine intensity” (RTI) and “offshorability” (OFFS) of jobs for use with the Luxembourg Income Study (LIS). To build the dataset, the PI and two graduate assistants recoded occupational schemes for 23 LIS countries and 74 LIS country-years into a common international standard—the International Standard Classification of Occupations 1988 (ISCO-88). When combining our recoded country-schemes with data from countries that already reported in ISCO-88 at a sufficient level of detail, we produced occa/b1, RTI and OFFS scores for 38 LIS countries and 160 LIS country-years. These data cover the period from the late 1960s to 2013. The new dataset provides an unparalleled degree of cross-national/temporal coverage and comparability for these job/occupational covariates. Measuring the skill, RTI and OFFS of jobs is a critical task in the contemporary period, because these occupational characteristics like at the core of three contending explanations for rising inequality—globalization, skill-biased technological change and financialization. The PI and a research assistant were recently invited to revise and resubmit a paper describing these new data for the International Journal of Comparative Sociology.

The second goal is to use these and other data to understand the causes of growing income inequality in advanced democracies. In one paper, now forthcoming in the journal Social Forces, we explicate the causal mechanisms by which offshoring increases inequality by changing the labor market returns to occupational characteristics in advanced countries. We then formulate a new argument to explain the mixed empirical support for these mechanisms in previous research. Here, we argue offshoring’s effects are conditional on processes that vary at the world-historical and national levels. We use macro-level data described in part by our initial proposal to test hypotheses consistent with these arguments. At the world-historical level, we show that offshoring had no effect on inequality before globalized production networks (GPNs) became a predominant organizational form world-wide. However, it has increasingly large effects on inequality as these organizational forms become entrenched world-wide. At the national level, we show that offshoring has no effect on inequality in countries with strong wage-coordinating institutions and welfare states. However, it has large, positive effects on inequality in countries where these institutions are weak. As can be seen in Figure 1, inequality would be much lower today if there were fewer GPNs, and if the prevailing degree of wage-coordination and welfare-state generosity were higher. These countervailing contextual effects raise important questions about distributional politics and outcomes in the future, and correlate fairly well with cross-national differences in the strength of extreme-right parties.

In second (unpublished) paper, we tackle the problem of income polarization and employ a portion of our new dataset to test hypotheses about an expanded set of potential explanations. We show that three types of distributional change are common in advanced countries--"downgrading" (a shift of households into the lowest income brackets over time), "upgrading" (a shift ofhouseholds into the highest income brackets over time), and "polarization" (a shift in households in both directions over time). However, upgrading is more common than downgrading. We then identify explanations at three levels of analysis: household composition (the rise of single-earning households, single female/mother heads and assortative mating) at the household level, skill and occupational stratification at the individual level, and socio-economic change (globalization, skill biased technological change and financialization) and institutional context (unions, wage-coordination and welfare states) at the macro (country-year) level. To assess the joint impacts of these processes, we derive a novel empirical strategy where by household income is modeled as a function of household composition, the labor market status of household earners, and the interaction of the latter with socio-economic change and institutional context. Our preliminary results suggest that socio-economic change appears to be the biggest driver of income polarization.

To facilitate the project’s broader impact, we will deposit our final dataset in the Luxembourg Income Study for use by future researchers. The Luxembourg Income Study is a living repository, however, as they continually introduce new national datasets. Thus, we also built a website that provides code to create these variables for future LIS datasets. In addition, the PI trained graduate research assistants to compile and manage large datasets, work within the LIS infrastructure and write research papers. Both research assistants have coauthored publications with the PI, and have or will use LIS data to conduct future research as a direct result of their training.
